HCAL 2915/2019.
The Hong Kong Journalist Association (HKJA) has today ( 3rd October 2019) invoked the supervisory jurisdiction of the High Court by filing a judicial review against the Commissioner of Police and the Secretary of Justice in order to establish (in summary) that:-
1. The Hong Kong Police Force (HKPF) is subject to a constitutional and public law duty to facilitate journalistic activities, including the scrutiny of HKPF actions; and/or
2. The HKPF has acted unlawfully in failing to facilitate, and in certain cases, actively hindered lawful journalistic activities, in breach of Articles 27 and 28 of the Basic law (BL) and Articles 3 and 6 of the HK Bill of Rights (‘HKBOR’) ; and/or
3. The Commissioner of Police, in failing or refusing to investigate and address the catalogue of operational deficiencies with regards to facilitating lawful journalistic activities in the course of recent protests, has acted unlawfully in breach of Article 29 of the BL and Article 16 of HKBOR; and/or
4. The Commissioner has acted unlawfully by failing to ensure that clearly visible individual identification is worn by all uniformed officers and all plainclothes police officers overtly exercising any public power, at public order events, contrary to Articles 27 and 28 of the BL and Articles 3 and 16 of HKBOR; and/ or
5. The Government of the HKSAR has a duty to establish a mechanism capable of effective and independent investigation of complaints against the police of ill-treatment falling within the scope of Article 3 HKBOR, including complaints brought by journalists, and that the existing complaints mechanisms of the Complaints Against Police Office (‘CAPO’) and the Independent Police Complaints Council (‘IPCC’) are inadequate to discharge this obligation.
This judicial review challenge references a catalogue of operational failings of the police concerning journalists, which have been brought to the attention of the Commissioner of Police by HKJA but have resulted in no remedial action, including:-
1. a pattern of obstructive tactics against the media, the deliberate withholding of police officers’ identities and repeated and systematic refusal by police to produce warrant cards during the execution ( or purported execution) of public duties, arresting and threatening journalists with arrest, using high intensity lights and strobe lighting to interfere with visual recording equipment, excluding reporters from relevant scenes and locations, deliberately blocking reporters' line of sight to reportable events with their bodies and/or shields (to prevent journalistic scrutiny), journalists being subjected to verbal abuse and insulting language; and
2. unnecessary and excessive force against journalists (presenting arguable claims of ill-treatment falling within the scope of Article 3 HKBOR), including journalists being beaten with truncheons and shields, kicked, pepper sprayed, being targeted with tear gas fired from tear gas launchers, having tear gas grenades thrown directly at them, water cannon directed at journalists, shooting at journalists with rubber bullets and bean bag rounds.
The above instances do not include the incidents that have occurred over the past 14 days, including the shooting of Ms. Veby Indah and other journalists.

速龍頭盔上的編號、防暴身上的行動呼號，不同警員之間會循環再用，更有警員刻意遮蓋而不受懲罰，結果受害者無法有效辨認黑警，全部違反人權法
'99. ...
(1) A Call-Sign is not unique to the police officer to whom it has been assigned (as in the case of an UI Number). After an officer who has been assigned a particular Call-Sign is transferred out of his platoon / team, the same Call-Sign is recycled and allocated to another officer taking up his position in the platoon / team. Moreover, the evidence before the court discloses instances where the same Call-Sign was worn and displayed by multiple officers on the same occasion, and also instances where police officers simply did not wear and display the Call-Signs, or used other objects to hide them from sight. While these may be said to be individual instances of failure of the system, there is absence of evidence that any adequate measure has been put in place by the Commissioner to ensure that the Call-Signs are properly worn and displayed by police officers deployed in Operation TIDERIDER, and to take action against officers who have failed to properly wear and display the Call-Signs.
(2) The Alpha ID system also suffers from the same deficiency that an Alpha ID is not unique to the police officer to whom it has been assigned (as in the case of an UI Number). The fact that the Alpha ID is only attached to the back of a STC officer’s helmet also substantially impairs its effectiveness as a means of identification. There were also instances where STC officers belonging to the same team and deployed at the same time and location did not attach the assigned letters to their helmets and only the team call sign was displayed. There is likewise an absence of evidence that any adequate measure has been put in place by the Commissioner to ensure that the Alpha IDs are properly attached to the helmets of STC officers deployed in Operation TIDERIDER, and to take action against officers who have failed to properly wear and display the Alpha IDs.'

'99. ...
(1) A Call-Sign is not unique to the police officer to whom it has been assigned (as in the case of an UI Number). After an officer who has been assigned a particular Call-Sign is transferred out of his platoon / team, the same Call-Sign is recycled and allocated to another officer taking up his position in the platoon / team. Moreover, the evidence before the court discloses instances where the same Call-Sign was worn and displayed by multiple officers on the same occasion, and also instances where police officers simply did not wear and display the Call-Signs, or used other objects to hide them from sight. While these may be said to be individual instances of failure of the system, there is absence of evidence that any adequate measure has been put in place by the Commissioner to ensure that the Call-Signs are properly worn and displayed by police officers deployed in Operation TIDERIDER, and to take action against officers who have failed to properly wear and display the Call-Signs.
(2) The Alpha ID system also suffers from the same deficiency that an Alpha ID is not unique to the police officer to whom it has been assigned (as in the case of an UI Number). The fact that the Alpha ID is only attached to the back of a STC officer’s helmet also substantially impairs its effectiveness as a means of identification. There were also instances where STC officers belonging to the same team and deployed at the same time and location did not attach the assigned letters to their helmets and only the team call sign was displayed. There is likewise an absence of evidence that any adequate measure has been put in place by the Commissioner to ensure that the Alpha IDs are properly attached to the helmets of STC officers deployed in Operation TIDERIDER, and to take action against officers who have failed to properly wear and display the Alpha IDs.'

'99. ...
(1) A Call-Sign is not unique to the police officer to whom it has been assigned (as in the case of an UI Number). After an officer who has been assigned a particular Call-Sign is transferred out of his platoon / team, the same Call-Sign is recycled and allocated to another officer taking up his position in the platoon / team. Moreover, the evidence before the court discloses instances where the same Call-Sign was worn and displayed by multiple officers on the same occasion, and also instances where police officers simply did not wear and display the Call-Signs, or used other objects to hide them from sight. While these may be said to be individual instances of failure of the system, there is absence of evidence that any adequate measure has been put in place by the Commissioner to ensure that the Call-Signs are properly worn and displayed by police officers deployed in Operation TIDERIDER, and to take action against officers who have failed to properly wear and display the Call-Signs.
(2) The Alpha ID system also suffers from the same deficiency that an Alpha ID is not unique to the police officer to whom it has been assigned (as in the case of an UI Number). The fact that the Alpha ID is only attached to the back of a STC officer’s helmet also substantially impairs its effectiveness as a means of identification. There were also instances where STC officers belonging to the same team and deployed at the same time and location did not attach the assigned letters to their helmets and only the team call sign was displayed. There is likewise an absence of evidence that any adequate measure has been put in place by the Commissioner to ensure that the Alpha IDs are properly attached to the helmets of STC officers deployed in Operation TIDERIDER, and to take action against officers who have failed to properly wear and display the Alpha IDs.'
